name: David Owen
comments: A Welsh harpist and composer, known as Dafydd y Garreg Wen.  There is some confusion about the true dates of birth and death; the memorial stone on his grave states that he died in 1749 aged 29, whereas christening records held at the National Library of Wales indicate that he was born blind in January of either 1711 or 1712.  Despite his blindness he became a harpist and composer of some note, writing a number of well-known airs including Codiad yr Ehedydd (The Rising of the Lark), which is played at the cenotaph in London every Remembrance Day.

name: S.A. Emery
comments: Stephen Emery was born in Maine and lived in New England for much of his life. In the early 1860s he studied music in Germany. In 1867 be began teaching at the New England Conservatory in Boston. Later he was appointed professor of Harmony and Counterpoint at Boston University. Many U.S. composers studied under Emery. He was the author of music text books as well as the composer of string quartets, sonatinas and other pieces for the pianoforte. He also wrote popular songs. One of these, a lullabye known as "Sleep, Baby, Sleep," was composed in 1869 and was a major hit that year. It was the second song recorded by Jimmie Rodgers in 1927 during his first recording session and it appeared on his first single.

name: Smiley Burnette
comments: Smiley Burnette was a comic cowboy, singer, songwriter, actor and musician from Illinois. Smiley played over 100 different instruments and, in some films, he played as many as 7 instruments simultaneously. In December 1933 Gene Autry hired him to play accordion on his National Barn Dance radio show based in Chicago. In 1934 Gene and Smiley headed west to Hollywood where they began long and successful film careers. They appeared together in many films and Gene sang several songs written by Smiley Burnette. In 1963 Smiley joined the cast of the popular TV show, "Petticoat Junction." He appeared in 105 episodes between 1963 and 1967.
